metadata.title: Epilepsy  Occupational Therapy
description: Epilepsy refers to a disorder with unprovoked, recurrent seizures.(8)Status epilepticus is defined, historically, as 30 minutes of continuous seizures or 2 or more seizures without full consciousness between them that are unprovoked(9)
A seizure is “a transient disturbance of cerebral function due to an abnormal paroxysmal neuronal discharge in the brain”(8)

Epilepsy is characterized by epilepsy type –Focal seizures start in a specific area of the brain and have localized symptoms(8) -Focal seizures are described by their features. Types of focal seizures include aura, motor, autonomic, and dyscognitive(6) -The International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) distinguishes between the following types of focal seizures:(8) -Motor vs non-motor  onset -Aware vs impaired awareness – awareness of self and environment during seizure -Focal to bilateral tonic-clonic  – progression from focal to generalized –Generalized seizures (also called tonic/clonic seizures) are abnormal electrical activity over both hemispheres of the brain.(8)There is usually loss of consciousness. These were formerly known as grand mal seizures -Types of generalized seizures include convulsive, absence (formerly known as petit mal), tonic, atonic, and myoclonic(6) -ILAE distinguishes between the following types of generalized seizures:(8) -Non-motor  (or absence) seizures – impairment in consciousness -Motor – tonic-clonic,  tonic, clonic, myoclonic, myoclonic-tonic-clonic, myotonic-atonic,  atonic, and epileptic spasms -If there is no recovery of consciousness between 2 seizures, this is called status epilepticus; if there is recovery of consciousness between, this is referred to as serial seizures –Seizures can also be considered combined generalized and focal if EEG shows signs of both(8)

Patients with seizures due to reversible causes (e.g., alcohol or drug withdrawal, hypo- or hyperglycemia) are not considered to have epilepsy(8) or application of equipment Impairment in driving/ decreased community participationImprove community participationFunctional training _ Teach use of technology to compensate, such as online banking, online shopping, delivery services _ _ Teach patient how to use public transportationProvide patient with simple tasks and increase to more complex tasks as he or she masters each community activity independentlyProvide patient and family/ caregivers with written instructions regarding a new community task to complete  Falls Increase safety in home; prevention of fallsPrescription, application of devices and equipment _ Bathroom safety equipment such as grab bars, shower chairs, nonslip matsN/A Provide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions regarding home safety tips Decreased medication complianceIncrease medication compliancePatient education _ Identify causes of medication noncompliance _ _ Education of patient and family about medication rationale _ _ Provide patient with choices, allow participation in medication planningN/A Provide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions for taking medication Decreased mobility Improve functional independent mobilityPrescription, application of devices and equipment _ Mobility aids, such as walkers, wheelchairs, electric scooters as appropriatePatient will use mobility devices safely and independently as prescribedProvide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions for safe use of mobility device . reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: Symptoms occurring during a seizure (can last from several minutes up to several hours)
Signs and symptoms depend on the part of the brain affected

Focal seizure symptoms(8) –Clonus – involuntary muscle contraction and relaxation in rapid succession –Tonic muscle – muscle rigidity –Decreased tone, flaccid extremity –Aphasia – impairment in understanding and expression of language –Temporary paralysis of muscle groups –Impaired consciousness – decreased alertness and responsiveness to external stimuli –Autonomic reactions: pupil dilation, stomach ache, vomiting, flushing, sweating, pallor, palpitations, salivation(6) –Paresthesias – abnormal sensations, such as pins and needles or burning sensations –Numbness –Distorted perception of body parts –Distorted sense of smell –Metallic taste in mouth –Dizziness –Visual distortions, such as flashing lights –Auditory disturbances, such as hissing, rushing sounds, or music –Distortion of sense of time, sensations of detachment and depersonalization –Illusions and hallucinations –Loss of consciousness with staring, eye fluttering, twitching of mouth or hands –Unconscious automatic behaviors, such as chewing, lip or tongue smacking, swallowing, clapping, scratching or other repetitive hand movements –Problems with memory

Generalized seizures(6) –Absence seizures – sudden onset, interruption of activities, blank stare, rotation of eyes upward –Eye blinking, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements)  –Change in muscle tone –Myoclonic contractions – brief, shock-like  contractions of muscles that can be generalized or occur in specific muscle groups –Spasms (in infants) – repetitive flexion/extension contractions throughout entire body –Tonic/clonic movement patterns – rigidity, then rapid contraction/relaxation of muscles, with loss of consciousness –Loss of postural muscle tone, causing fall (atonic seizures –sudden loss of tone)

Atypical presentation in older adults should be noted – may be confused with dementia. May present as confusion, memory lapses, change in mental status and staring –Incidence is high in older adults and increases with age Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Ensure safety of patient during examination, sufficient room for physical assessment, and removal of environmental hazards

causes: ILAE distinguishes between6 broad etiologies with subdivisions(8)–Structural etiology-Pediatric age groups – congenital or due to perinatal injury-Mesial temporal sclerosis-Trauma-Tumors and other space-occupying  lesions-Vascular – due to stroke and other vascular diseases-Degenerative disorders (e.g., Alzheimer’s disease)–Genetic etiology – autosomal dominant or may cause a metabolic basis–Infectious etiology (e.g., bacterial meningitis, herpes encephalitis, AIDS)–Metabolic etiology (e.g., pyridoxine deficiency, mitochondrial disease)–Immune etiology (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus)–Unknown etiology
pathogenesis ,: In focal seizures, a limited and localized part of one cerebral hemisphere is activated
Generalized seizures are thought to originate in or spread rapidly to both hemispheres and involve both cortical networks
In status epilepticus, brain injury can occur if seizure activity is not controlled
risk factors ,: Febrile seizures that last unusually long
Meningitis, encephalitis, brain tumors, and traumatic brain injury
Family history of seizures, family history of febrile seizures
Specific stimuli (e.g., flashing lights) – known as photosensitive epilepsy

overall contraindications precautions: Safety is of utmost concern for patients with epilepsy; injuries can occur during seizure activity

First aid for seizures includes the following:(10) Removing hazards Stay with patient until he or she regains consciousness Avoid restraints unless there is sudden danger Turn on side to keep airway clear Put something soft under head Loosen tight clothing  Call 911 if seizure lasts more than 10 minutes Do not put anything in mouth
When working with children, obtain necessary parental consent according to facility’s policies and procedures
Avoid triggers (e.g., flashing bright lights or patterns, increased stress)(4)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Ensure safety of patient during examination, sufficient room for physical assessment, and removal of environmental hazards

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Ask patient or family about initial diagnosis of epilepsy and occurrence of first seizure. Was there an event, injury, or illness related to the onset of epilepsy (e.g., stroke, TBI, brain tumor)? Document if there are triggering factors to seizures

course of treatment.medical management: Determine what course of treatment has been taken
surgical management: Surgical management:  Document if surgery was utilized. Normally, surgery is considered only when seizures are refractory to two or more medications(8)
Resective surgery  is most effective when there is a single, well-defined  locus in temporal lobe
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Determine if patient has had any medication side effects and whether seizure frequency has been reduced or eliminated by medications Antiepileptic drug side effects include drowsiness, dizziness,and vertigo, and may worsen depression or provoke suicidal ideation or actions(8) Antiepileptic drugs and additional potential side effects(2,3) Valproic acid (Depakene) can cause nausea, vomiting, temporary hair thinning or loss, weight gain(2) Carbamazepine (Tegretol) can cause upset stomach, skin reactions, blood disorders(2) Phenytoin (Dilantin) can cause body hair growth, gum disease, seizures (with high doses)(2) Benzodiazepines (Valium, Ativan, Klonopin, Onfi) can cause sedation, dependence, respiratory depression, risk of glaucoma, risk of severe seizures with sudden withdrawal(2) Medications used vary by form of epilepsy. For refractory and super-refractory  status epilepticus, the most severe form of epilepsy, there is no strong evidence to support pharmacological recommendations for management(7)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Continuous video EEG in refractory cases(9)
Prolonged clinical observation  can occur as an outpatient for 6–8 hours or inpatient over 24 hours
Lab tests: e.g., electrolytes, drug levels
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of complementary or alternative therapies and whether or not they help Various suggestions have included yoga, relaxation training, biofeedback, omega fatty acids, acupuncture, and ketogenic diet, but none are considered standard of care Authors of a systematic review suggest that the music of Mozart has an effect on epilepsy in the form of reducing epileptiform discharges or seizures in children. It is suggested as a possible treatment when medication or surgery is not acceptable(12)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical, occupational, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Determine the frequency of seizures and any factors such as weather or time of day that affect the onset of seizures. Common triggers include missed medications, sleep deprivation, stress, substance abuse, hormonal changes due to menstrual cycles, and flashing bright lights(4)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of seizures (myoclonus in specific muscle groups)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document seizure activity throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document any changes in seizure activity due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to epilepsy diagnosis. Document if there are sleep disorders present, such as insomnia or sleep apnea
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any need for supplemental oxygen or the need for ventilation Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________ -Prevalence of epilepsy increases with increasing intellectual disability(5) -Based on a systematic review and meta-analysis of 48 studies (46 used in the meta-analysis) -Authors of a systematic review on the prevalence of epilepsy in autistic spectrum disorder (ASD) reported that increased prevalence of epilepsy was associated with greater intellectual disability and younger age(13)

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Ask if patient has history of febrile seizures or other neurological diagnosis Ask if patient has any stimulators implanted (i.e., receiving deep brain stimulation)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Comorbid diagnoses Ask patient/family/caregiver about other problems, including developmental disabilities, intellectual disabilities, depression, macroencephaly, diabetes, brain tumors, migraines, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, dementia, sleep disorders, and multiple sclerosis
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in any sports or recreational activities? -What is patient’s job? Is the patient in school? Does seizure activity interfere with ability to safely perform tasks and responsibilities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Determine if patient is using any home safety equipment -Ask about patient’s driving status, ability to participate in community activities, and what types of transportation adaptations are being used -Does the patient use an ambulatory device? If so, what type of device? -Ask if patient requires use of hearing aids or glasses
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -Ask about stairs, floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. -Identify if there are barriers to independence and safety in the home; any modifications necessary? -Identify home safety equipment in place in the home in case of seizures, especially in bathroom and kitchen  -Inquire about psychosocial issues (e.g., related to stigma)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Assess fit and appropriate use of functional mobility devices, such as walker or wheelchair –Protective helmet may be used to protect head during seizures/falls
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess postural balance -Static posturography can be assessed using the Posture Scale Analyzer (PSA) system Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) –Observe patient’s ability to access environment; any use of mobility aids required? –Observe functional transfers such as shower, toilet, and bed; check for safety Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Assess hand dominance, bilateral integration, manual dexterity (Purdue Pegboard test), and muscle tone
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Muscle strength -Manual muscle testing (MMT) as appropriate -Pinch and grip strength (pinchmeter and dynamometer) Neuromotor development –Bilateral integration and motor praxis –Is there any delay in acquisition of motor skills? (e.g., use Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition [PDMS-2]) Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations) –Assess visual perceptual skills as they affect learning and driving -Developmental Test of Visual Motor Integration
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Observe posture in standing and sitting and document deviations
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Passive and active ROM of upper extremity measured using goniometry as appropriate –Assess muscle tone during ROM test Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –Assess independence and quality of movement during performance of self-care  tasks (e.g., grooming, toileting) –FIM
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Assess tactile sensation using variety of modalities, such as light touch, pinprick, vibration, and temperature –Assess proprioception and kinesthesia
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Glasgow Epilepsy Outcome Scale (GEOS-C)  – client interview assessment to identify and prioritize concerns of adults with epilepsy and intellectual disability
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Assess attention span, ability to follow directions, decision making, problem-solving  abilities, memory, and ability to retain information

contraindications precautions: Stay with patient until he or she regains consciousness
Avoid restraints unless there is sudden danger
Turn on side to keep airway clear
Call 911 if seizure lasts more than 10 minutes
Do not put anything in mouth
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Ensure that patient and patient’s caregiver are involved in setting goals(3)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Referral to occupational therapy after epilepsy surgery for psychosocial adjustment and rehabilitation Epilepsy’s impact on daily function, school, or work activities may warrant occupational therapy assessment and treatment Epilepsy may be a comorbid condition. Patient may require treatment for impairments caused by the condition that is the underlying cause of epilepsy, such as stroke or traumatic brain injury (TBI)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Differential diagnosis for focal seizures(8) –TIAs –Migraine aura –Panic attacks –Rage attacks Differential diagnosis for generalized seizure(8) –Syncope –Cardiac disease –Brainstem ischemia –Psychogenic nonepileptic seizures
prognosis: Prognosis depends on types of seizure and brain pathology(8) –Overall, 25–30%  of seizures are refractory to medications(11) –Patients with epilepsy can lead normal lives(9) –The risk of seizure after mild TBI remains high for a long period (> 10 years)(11)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Psychology for counseling needs Neuropsychology for assessment of learning ability Physical therapy for mobility, gait concerns Speech therapy for cognitive deficits related to communication Developmental ophthalmologist for visual perceptual problems Audiology for any hearing deficits Learning specialist for concerns about learning and attention at school Endocrinologist for hormonal dysregulation concerns related to antiepileptic drugs Support groups
other considerations: Important to note: sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) can occur(3)
Goals of rehabilitation should take into consideration family, community, and psychosocial factors to maximize outcomes
treatment summary: Although RCTs have not shown direct effects of OT, occupational therapists are seen as instrumental parts of the multidisciplinary team in the management of epilepsy(14)

A short-term  multidisciplinary program was shown to have promise for over 50% of patients with epilepsy studied, especially in the areas of compliance, activity, and affect(14) –Developed in Germany, 1339 patients participated in the program 8 times –The program included education/training of cognitive functions (e.g., attention, executive functions, memory strategies, and language), physical fitness and motor coordination exercises, therapeutic counseling to enhance coping with the disease and its consequences, information about metacognition for a better understanding of epilepsy, education in  strategies for seizure self-control  and reducing provoking factors, mindfulness training for relaxation, and advice in social law –The authors suggest further development of multidisciplinary programs

Another program that was found to have benefits for children and adolescents with epilepsy was a minimally structured psychoeducational intervention aimed at improving self-regulation(15) –The intervention consisted of one 4-hour  session using cognitive behavioral therapy techniques, relaxation techniques, videos, and storytelling –Illness perceptions (Brief Illness Perception Questionnaire), psychological distress (Revised Children's Anxiety and Depression Scale), sleep problems, and somatic complaints were assessed . maintenance or prevention: Maintenance and prevention will depend on the functional limitations present for the person with epilepsy. For example, a person with absence seizures will need home and community safety training for prevention of injury in case of seizure
Safety in the home and in the community will be the priority for patients with epilepsy
Adequate rest, avoidance of triggers may help prevent seizures
Wearing a helmet to prevent head injury when cycling, skiing, motorcycling
